com.swirlds.platform

Class AddressBook

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.swirlds.platform.AddressBook
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    FastCopyable

    public class AddressBook
extends java.lang.Object
implements FastCopyable
    The Address of every known member of the swirld. The getters are public and the setters aren't, so it is read-only for apps.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      AddressBook()
      Create an empty address book.
      AddressBook(java.util.List<Address> addresses)
      Create an address book initialized with the given list of addresses.

    • Constructor Detail

      • AddressBook

        public AddressBook()
        Create an empty address book. Only classes in the com.swirlds.platform package can add to it.

      • AddressBook

        public AddressBook(java.util.List<Address> addresses)
        Create an address book initialized with the given list of addresses. Any class can instantiate this and set up the initial list of addresses. Only classes in the com.swirlds.platform package can add to it.
        Parameters:
        addresses - the addresses to start with

    • Method Detail

      • immutableCopy

        public AddressBook immutableCopy()
        return an exact copy of this AddressBook, except that it is immutable
        Returns:
        an immutable copy of the address book

      • isImmutable

        public boolean isImmutable()
        Is this address book immutable? The mutability of the address book cannot be changed. But a copy of it can be made that is mutable or immutable by calling copy or immutableCopy, respectively. Note that each Address in the book is always immutable. It's only the list and map of the AddressBook that is mutable vs immutable.
        Returns:
        true if this AddressBook is immutable

      • getSize

        public int getSize()
        Get the number of addresses currently in the address book.
        Returns:
        the number of addresses

      • getOwnHostCount

        public int getOwnHostCount()
        Get the number of addresses currently in the address book that are running on this computer. When the browser is run with a config.txt file, it can launch multiple copies of the app simultaneously, each with its own TCP/IP port. This method returns how many there are.
        Returns:
        the number of local addresses

      • getId

        public long getId(java.lang.String publicKey)
        Find the ID for the member whose address has the given public key. for now, this uses the nickname instead of the public key. Returns -1 if it does not exist.
        Parameters:
        publicKey - the public key to look up
        Returns:
        the ID of the member with that key, or -1 if it was not found

      • getAddress

        public Address getAddress(long id)
        Get the address for the member with the given ID
        Parameters:
        id - the member ID of the address to get
        Returns:
        the address or null if it doesn't exist

      • copy

        public AddressBook copy()
        Description copied from interface: FastCopyable
        If a class ExampleClass implements the FastCopyable interface, and an object x is of class ExampleClass, then x.copy() instantiates and returns a new ExampleClass object containing the same data as x. This should be a deep clone, not shallow. So if x contains references to other objects, it should do something like copy() on them, too, rather than just copying the reference.

        Furthermore, the copy operation should be fast, at the possible cost of making reads and writes slower (such as by using some kind of copy-on-write mechanism).

        Specified by:
        copy in interface FastCopyable
        Returns:
        the new copy that was made

      • copyTo

        public void copyTo(FCDataOutputStream outStream)
            throws java.io.IOException
        Serialize this to the given DataOutputStream. The generated bytes must be a deterministic function of the important state of this.

        So, for example, a HashMap shouldn't be serialized by simply using the iterator and writing each entry, because two computers with identical entries in their HashMaps might iterate in a different order, generating different sequences of bytes. This is why it is incorrect to wrap outStream in a ObjectOutputStream, because there is no guarantee of consistent encoding.

        If object x is of class X, which is a FastCopyable, then X must implement copyTo. If y is an integer variable in X, then the method X.copyTo(FCDataOutputStream fcdos) will need to serialize y by doing something like fcdos.writeInt(y). If z is of class Z and is a variable in X, then x.copyTo might serialize it by calling z.copyTo(fcdos). However, care must be taken to avoid cycles. If Z contains a variable of type X, then it would be bad for Z.copyTo to call x.copyTo, because that would lead to infinite recursion.

        If x contains a variable z of class Z, and Z is a FastCopyable provided by the Swirlds platform, then it will always be safe to serialize it by calling z.copyTo(fcdos). In some cases, the platform may even implement additional optimizations. But the effect will be same as if z.copyTo(fcdos) was sending itself to fcdos as a sequence of bytes.

        Specified by:
        copyTo in interface FastCopyable
        Parameters:
        outStream - the stream to write to
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - can be thrown by the DataOutputStream while writing to it

      • copyFrom

        public void copyFrom(FCDataInputStream inStream)
              throws java.io.IOException
        Make this object be an exact copy of the object that was serialized to the given stream. It should overwrite all the existing state within this object, and replace it.

        It can be assumed that the stream was originally written by the copyTo method. There may be bytes in the stream after the ones to read here, so it is important to know when this has finished reading its state (e.g., by making copyTo write the length of an array before writing all its elements).

        Specified by:
        copyFrom in interface FastCopyable
        Parameters:
        inStream - the stream to read from
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - can be thrown by the DataInputStream while reading from it
